ebnm: Solve the empirical Bayes normal means problem

The ebnm package provides functions to solve the (heteroskedastic) â€œempirical Bayes normal meansâ€ (EBNM) problem for various choices of prior family. The model is

xjÂ |Â Î¸j,Â sjâ€„âˆ¼â€„N(Î¸j,Â sj2)

Î¸jÂ |Â sjâ€„âˆ¼â€„gâ€„âˆˆâ€„ğ’¢

where the distribution g is to be estimated. The distribution g is referred to as the â€œprior distributionâ€ for Î¸ and ğ’¢ is a specified family of prior distributions. Several options for ğ’¢ are implemented, some parametric and others non-parametric; see below for examples.

Solving the EBNM problem involves two steps. First, estimate gâ€„âˆˆâ€„ğ’¢ via maximum marginal likelihood, yielding an estimate

gÌ‚â€„:=â€„argâ€†maxgâ€„âˆˆâ€„ğ’¢Â L(g)

where

L(g)â€„:=â€„Î jÂ âˆ«Â p(xjÂ |Â Î¸j,Â sj)Â g(dÎ¸j)

Second, compute the posterior distributions p(Î¸jÂ |Â xj,Â sj,Â gÌ‚) and/or summaries such as posterior means and posterior second moments.

The prior families that have been implemented include:

â€œpoint_normalâ€: The family of mixtures where one component is a point mass at Î¼ and the other is a normal distribution centered at Î¼.

â€œpoint_laplaceâ€: The family of mixtures where one component is a point mass at zero and the other is a double-exponential distribution.

â€œpoint_exponentialâ€: The family of mixtures where one component is a point mass at zero and the other is a (nonnegative) exponential distribution.

â€œnormalâ€: The family of normal distributions.

â€œhorseshoeâ€: The family of horseshoe distributions.

â€œnormal_scale_mixtureâ€: The family of scale mixtures of normals.

â€œunimodalâ€: The family of all unimodal distributions.

â€œunimodal_symmetricâ€: The family of symmetric unimodal distributions.

â€œunimodal_nonnegativeâ€: The family of unimodal distributions with support constrained to be greater than the mode.

â€œunimodal_nonpositiveâ€: The family of unimodal distributions with support constrained to be less than the mode.

â€œgeneralized_binaryâ€: The family of mixtures where one component is a point mass at zero and the other is a truncated normal distribution with lower bound zero and nonzero mode.

â€œnpmleâ€: The family of all distributions.

â€œdeconvolverâ€: A non-parametric exponential family with a natural spline basis. Like npmle, there is no unimodal assumption, but whereas npmle produces spiky estimates for g, deconvolver estimates are much more regular. See Narasimhan and Efron (2020) for details.

â€œflatâ€: A â€œnon-informativeâ€ improper uniform prior.

â€œpoint_massâ€: The family of all point masses.

License

The ebnm source code repository is free software: you can redistribute it under the terms of the GNU General Public License. All the files in this project are part of ebnm. This project is distributed in the hope that it will be useful, but without any warranty; without even the implied warranty of merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose.

Quick Start

Install the ebnm package:

install.packages("ebnm")

Load ebnm into your R environment, and get help:

library(ebnm)
?ebnm

Try an example:

set.seed(1)
theta = c(rep(0, 500), rnorm(500)) # true means
x = theta + rnorm(1000) # observations with standard error 1
ebnm_res = ebnm_point_normal(x, 1)
plot(ebnm_res)
